results.title: The Eye inside
results.brief_description:
“With this work I am interested in questions of personal identity. What is it? Can you capture it in a photograph? What would you need to do in that photograph to be acting as the real you? How can you protect your own sense of identity in the face of external pressure?

Using notorious archival photographs of ‘hysterical’ patients as the starting point, I wanted to re-examine what was actually being revealed in these strange images to us, contemporary viewers. The body language we see was heavily influenced by popular culture of the period, particularly the theatre and religious imagery, and also distorted by the doctors’ trials with hypnotism. But there is clearly a conflict between these female patients’ own sense of identity, emerging as the psychic pain they metaphorically express with their bodies, and that of the male doctors/ photographers’ conception of them.

I was interested in applying a similar pseudo-medical method of observing and photographing to displays of specific contemporary body language: again female, again familiar from popular culture. Would the distinction between personal identity and cultural identity be obvious? How far would these healthy, sane modes of behaviour need exaggeration to be classified as unhealthy or mad? This work is an initial investigation into these themes.”
Cordelia Beresford, 2004.

Duration: 2 x 8 minute video piece, looped as per duration required by ACMI specifications (ie it will play 3 loops continuously if possible- tbc). The second 8 minute piece is a variation
(ie different edit only) of the first. Both are to be played simultaneously on two or more screens.

Shoot Format: 16mm film and 35mm still photographs, both mastered to digital-beta tape. Black & white.

Delivery Format: Digital-Betacam tape, 60 minutes length.

Sound: the work is silent.

results.title: The Eye hears the ear sees
results.creator_credit: Margaret Dale, ONF | NFB, British Broadcasting Corporation and Gavin Millar
results.brief_description: Shakespeare said it first, but here Gavin Millar of the BBC employs the phrase as a tribute to the unique filmmaking career of Norman McLaren. Millar talks with McLaren and another National Film Board film animator, Grant Munro, and shows many examples of the development of the McLaren style. It shows examples of his multiple exposure effects. Demonstrates how he makes moving pictures without cameras and sound tracks without instruments. Includes excerpts from his films, Hen hop, Pas de deux, etc. Photography by Robert Humble. (Awards: New York; Montevideo; Philadelphia.)

results.title: The Extraordinary experience of Nicholas Nodwell
results.brief_description: Nicholas is usually inattentive at school and likes to daydream. During a lesson on the production and uses of petroleum he finds himself transported into a strange world without petroleum. He learns how much our modern society depends on petroleum products. Script by Frank Colyer.

results.title: The Extraordinary adventures of the mouse and his child
results.creator_credit: Walt de Faria, deFaria-Lockhart Productions, Sanrio America, Fred Wolf and Charles Swenson
results.brief_description: This animated story of the thrilling adventures of a toy mouse and his child is based on the modern classic of children’s fiction written by Russell Hoban. From their home in the toy shop window, the mouse and his child find themselves cast into a rubbish tip where they become prisoners of the slimy rat, Manny (voice of Peter Ustinov). Helped by their friends, a fortune-telling rat, an actress parrot, a performing seal and a pink elephant, the mouse and his child plot to escape Manny’s evil clutches and discover how they can become self-winding.

results.title: The Expressive arts: everyone succeeds!
results.creator_credit: Malcolm Smith, South Australian Film Corporation and Ron Saunders
results.brief_description: Subjects such as music, drama, painting, pottery, sculpture and weaving are now being taught in schools. The study of these subjects is seen to enhance the social, physical, and emotional development of students, and it is argued that students are also inspired to put more effort into the traditional academic subjects. Photography by Edwin Scragg and edited by Wayne Le Clos.

results.title: The Expressionist eye
results.creator_credit: Malcolm Otton, David Muir, Australian National Gallery and Film Australia
results.brief_description:
Episode number 19 of Series “The Australian eye IV”.
Recollections of Melbourne in the 1940s. Examines the rise of artists: Arthur Boyd, Josl Bergner, Joy Hester, Sidney Nolan, John Perceval, Albert Tucker Danila Vassilief, John Reed, Peter Herbst, Barrett Reid and Bernard Smith. This film provides an understanding of that rebellious period when the course of Australian art took a new direction under European Expressionism.
